Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Workplace Wearable Device For Social Distancing and Contact Tracing in Essential Businesses During COVID-19
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to protect the public during the COVID-19 pandemic through contact tracing. This project will develop wearable technology to provide proximity alerts when workers are in close contact, creating awareness around social distancing. It will also record every contact between workers to provide contact tracing should a worker test positive for COVID-19. These tools protect front-line workers from the spread of the virus, along with their families and communities. The technology will extend existing wearable technology to reduce overexertion injuries in the workplace.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will estimate distance between workers through a machine learning algorithm combining signal strength from Bluetooth technology with motion sensor data from accelerometers and gyroscopes to measure worker activity prior and at the end of each contact event. The project will develop distance detection algorithms and a set of performance requirements to optimize design of a rapid, accurate solution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to extend the use of an internet connected wearable device - currently worn by industrial workers in the manufacturing, logistics and distribution industries – to help ensure the safety of workers in essential businesses during the current COVID-19 pandemic.

This was achieved by developing a novel tool which:

  • Provided real-time alers to workers wearing the device whenever they were within 6 feet of another worker. This was provided through a light vibration.
  • Collect and record data of the number of close contacts that occur in a facility
  • Provide contact tracing information in an easy to use software dashboard to help identify workers that need to be quarantined in the case of an in-plant infection

The technology developed to enable these tools was developed as a result of this research grant, and involved using bluetooth signals in the device to estimate distance between workers, and to provide robust means of communications between devices to accurately keep track of the duration of contacts. To develop the algorithms, a large dataset was collected with devices placed at different distances from each other. A machine learning algorithm used multiple features derived from the bluetooth signal to estimate distance between devices as well as contact duration.

Customers at 6 facilities were interviewed to develop requirements for both the nature of the real-time feedback to be provided to workers as well as the features needed to accuractely perform contact tracing following CDC guidelines. These led to outcomes that have been incorporated into our current product in the field, and are currently in use by hundreds of workers.

As next steps for the technology, there are two directions the technology will take going forward: i) continued innovation to protect workers from COVID-19 infection and ii) exploration of additional features to add to the wearable device to protect workers from other injuries and illnesses.
